questions.text: Eonism can be defined as? (INICET NOVEMBER 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Wearing clothes of opposite sex

 

  • Eonism /Transvestism involves wearing clothes of the opposite sex to derive pleasure.
  • Eonism is named for Charles Eon de Beaumont, a French political adventurer who died in 1810 after posing as a woman for many years.

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Public display of genitalia – Exhibitionism, where an individual derives pleasure from exposing their genitals to others in public.

 

Option C. Seeing a male undressing: This can be a form of voyeurism, though it is not specifically defined as such. Voyeurism typically involves deriving pleasure from secretly observing others who are undressing or engaging in sexual activities.

 

Option D. Seeing a female undressing- Voyeurism, where an individual derives pleasure from observing females undressing.

 

Educational Objective

 

Eonism or transvestism is the act of wearing clothes of the opposite sex for pleasure, named after Charles Eon de Beaumont.

questions.text: A 6-year-old boy presents to the clinic with his mother, who is concerned about his nasal-sounding voice. She reports that her son seems to be frequently "talking through his nose," especially when he is trying to pronounce 'm' and 'n' sounds. Additionally, she mentions that he breathes through his mouth most of the time, especially at night, and has been having difficulty sleeping. On examination, the boy has no signs of acute respiratory distress but does have a hyponasal voice. Xray reveals enlarged adenoids obstructing the nasopharynx. No other abnormalities are noted. What type of voice change is most likely present in this patient due to his enlarged adenoids? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Rhinorrhea clausa

 

Given the context of adenoid enlargement affecting the voice, the most likely associated voice change would be Option A, Rhinolalia clausa, because enlarged adenoids can block the nasal passages and affect the normal resonance of speech.

 

Rhinolalia clausa is characterized by a nasal quality to the voice due to blockage in the nasal passages, which could be caused by enlarged adenoids. This blockage prevents normal resonance in the nasal cavities, leading to a muffled, nasal-sounding voice.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Rhinolalia aperta refers to a voice that sounds excessively nasal due to inadequate closure of the velopharyngeal sphincter, usually not directly associated with adenoid hypertrophy.

 

Option C. A hot potato voice is typically described as a muffled and garbled voice, as if speaking with a hot potato in the mouth. This is often found in conditions such as a peritonsillar abscess rather than adenoid enlargement.

 

Option D. Echolalia is the repetition of phrases or sounds and is a communication disorder. It is not a type of voice quality and is not related to adenoids or their enlargement.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The voice of a patient with enlarged adenoids is likely to exhibit Rhinolalia clausa, characterized by a nasal quality due to obstruction of the nasal passages.

questions.text: A 70-year-old man with a known history of DM and HTN on regular medications presents with a history of progressively worsening dyspnea on exertion. On examination, there is elevated JVP, positive hepatojugular reflux, crackles at the lung bases, hepatomegaly, ascites, and pedal oedema. What is your provisional diagnosis? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Heart failure

 

The patient's symptoms and clinical findings are indicative of congestive heart failure (CHF), specifically biventricular failure. The elevated JVP, positive hepatojugular reflux, hepatomegaly, ascites, and pedal edema are typical signs of right heart failure, which suggests poor venous return management by the heart. Additionally, the presence of crackles at the lung bases points to left ventricular failure, which often presents with pulmonary congestion due to backflow of blood into the pulmonary circulation. This combination points to heart failure involving both the left and right sides of the heart (biventricular failure).

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy: While this condition can cause symptoms of heart failure, the presentation would typically include other specific signs such as a systolic murmur best heard at the left sternal border and possibly signs of dynamic outflow obstruction, which are not specifically mentioned here.

 

Option C. Mitral regurgitation: Mitral regurgitation could present with symptoms similar to heart failure; however, a hallmark sign would be a pan-systolic murmur heard best at the apex and radiating to the axilla, which isn't mentioned. The systemic signs such as hepatomegaly and ascites are less commonly associated with isolated mitral regurgitation unless it has led to significant heart failure.

 

Option D. Portal hypertension: This condition would explain hepatomegaly and ascites but would not typically include pulmonary symptoms like crackles at the lung bases or findings like elevated JVP and positive hepatojugular reflux without concurrent heart failure.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The constellation of symptoms such as elevated JVP, systemic edema (hepatomegaly, ascites, pedal edema), and pulmonary findings (crackles at the lung bases) strongly suggests heart failure, likely due to the patient's known history of hypertension and diabetes contributing to chronic cardiac stress and dysfunction.

 

Reference - Harrison/Clinical Cardiology/Chap 239

questions.text:
The following are parvovirus-related manifestations. Identify the incorrect pair? (INICET NOV 2022)

 

  1. Pure red cell aplasia - chronic hemolytic anemia
  2. Polymyalgia rheumatica - young women
  3. Hydrops fetalis - pregnant women
  4. Erythema infectiosum - infants
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 2

 

Polymyalgia rheumatica is closely associated with giant cell arteritis in women above 50yrs.

 

Other Options:

 

1. Pure red cell aplasia - chronic hemolytic anemia: Parvovirus B19 can cause pure red cell aplasia, particularly in patients with chronic hemolytic anemia. The virus affects erythroid precursors in the bone marrow, leading to severe anemia in these patients.

 

3. Hydrops fetalis - pregnant women: Parvovirus B19 infection during pregnancy can lead to severe fetal complications, including hydrops fetalis, which is a life-threatening condition characterized by severe edema in the fetus.

 

4. Erythema infectiosum - infants: Erythema infectiosum, also known as fifth disease or slapped-cheek disease, is a common manifestation of parvovirus B19 infection in young children, not just infants. It presents with a characteristic "slapped cheek" rash.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Polymyalgia rheumatica is typically seen in women above 50 years old and is not related to parvovirus infection in young women. Parvovirus B19 is more commonly associated with conditions such as erythema infectiosum in children, pure red cell aplasia in patients with chronic hemolytic anemia, and hydrops fetalis in pregnant women.

 

Additional Information

 

Parvo virus infection -

 

Common symptoms of parvovirus B19 (B19V) infection include a mild nonspecific prodromal illness that may consist of fever (15-30% of patients), malaise, headache, myalgia, nausea, and rhinorrhea; typically beginning 5-7 days after initial infection

 

A diffuse maculopapular rash can appear 1-4 days later and fades to a lacy erythematous rash, which may be pruritic and may spread gradually toward the distal extremities. Most seropositive patients have no history of this classic biphasic illness. The clinical symptoms widely vary, and the classic "slapped cheek" rash is much more common in young children called as erythema infectiosum, also known as fifth disease or slapped-cheek disease,

 

 

Alternatively, parvovirus B19 infection may manifest with purpuric rash, erythema multiforme, or pruritus of the soles of the feet. Parvovirus B19 may cause a papular-purpuric "gloves-and-socks" syndrome (PPGSS), which manifests as an erythematous exanthem of the hands and feet with a distinct margin at the wrist and ankle joints.

 

Transient small joint arthropathy may be the main clinical presentation of parvovirus B19 in adults.

 

Pure red cell aplasia and chronic hemolytic anemia is seen  in patients with immunosuppression.

 

Patients with severe anemia due to transient aplastic crisis (TAC) may present with pallor, fatigue, or signs of an aplastic crisis.

 

Parvovirus B19V infection during pregnancy can lead to hydrops fetalis and/or fetal loss.

questions.text: A patient presented with unilateral proptosis and bilateral abducent palsy. What is the most probable cause?  (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Cavernous sinus thrombosis

 

  • Clinical scenario suggests cavernous sinus thrombosis.
  • Features include early involvement of lateral rectus palsy due to involvement of abducent nerve passing through the cavernous sinus.
  • Later involvement of oculomotor and trochlear nerve palsy, related to the lateral wall of cavernous sinus.

*image added

 

 

  • Other signs include proptosis, severe supraorbital pain, edema in mastoid region, absence of corneal sensation, and dilated pupil.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Options A. Retinoblastoma: Occurs in young children and presents with unilateral proptosis with leukocoria, buphthalmos, and squint.

 

Option B. Orbital pseudotumor: Presents with unilateral proptosis with diplopia, conjunctival chemosis. The inflammation is responsive to systemic corticosteroids.

 

Option C. Orbital cellulitis: Presents with unilateral proptosis with pain and decreased ocular motility.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cavernous sinus thrombosis is a medical emergency. Rapid recognition and aggressive treatment are essential to prevent serious complications and improve patient outcomes.

questions.text:
What is the antidote of cyanide poisoning? (INICET MAY 2024)

 

A. Amyl Nitrite
B. Sodium Nitrite
C. Sodium Thiosulphate
D. Benzyl Thiocyanate
E. Sodium Nitroprusside
questions.solution:
Ans. A) ABC

 

Cyanide poisoning inhibits cytochrome C oxidase, a key enzyme in the mitochondrial electron transport chain, leading to cellular hypoxia and lactic acidosis. The treatment for cyanide poisoning involves agents that either bind to cyanide, facilitating its excretion, or convert it into a less toxic form.

 

A. Amyl Nitrite and B. Sodium Nitrite: These compounds oxidize hemoglobin to methemoglobin, which has a higher affinity for cyanide than cytochrome C oxidase. This process frees cytochrome C oxidase and forms cyanmethemoglobin.

 

C. Sodium Thiosulphate: This compound acts directly by converting cyanmethemoglobin to thiocyanate, which is less toxic and is excreted in the urine. Additionally, it directly breaks the bond between cytochrome C oxidase and cyanide.

 

D. Benzyl Thiocyanate: This is not a recognized treatment for cyanide poisoning and does not have the properties needed to detoxify cyanide.

 

E. Sodium Nitroprusside: This compound, while containing cyanide groups, is not used as an antidote for cyanide poisoning. It is actually a source of cyanide and is used for different medical purposes, such as vasodilation in hypertensive emergencies.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The main antidotes for cyanide poisoning include amyl nitrite, sodium nitrite, and sodium thiosulphate. These agents work by either converting cyanide into a less toxic form or by forming methemoglobin which binds to cyanide, freeing cytochrome C oxidase.

choices.text: Decrease scavanging of RBC by macrophages

questions.text: What is seen in G6PD deficiency? (INICET May 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Decrease generation of reduced glutathione

 

G6PD deficiency results in reduced production of reduced glutathione (GSH), an important antioxidant in red blood cells. This decrease in GSH levels impairs the cell's ability to neutralize harmful reactive oxygen species (ROS) and, as a result, increases oxidative stress and damage to red blood cells.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Decrease membrane lipid peroxidation: G6PD deficiency can lead to a decrease in reduced glutathione levels, which normally help protect red blood cell membranes from oxidative damage. Therefore, a deficiency in G6PD can actually increase membrane lipid peroxidation, making red blood cells more susceptible to damage from oxidative stress.

 

Option C. Decrease NADH generation: G6PD deficiency primarily affects the production of NADPH (not NADH), which is essential for the regeneration of reduced glutathione and the maintenance of antioxidant defenses in red blood cells. NADPH is crucial in protecting red blood cells from oxidative damage.

 

Option D. Decrease scavenging of RBC by macrophages: G6PD deficiency can actually increase the susceptibility of red blood cells to phagocytosis by macrophages. The oxidative stress and damage to red blood cells caused by G6PD deficiency can lead to the removal of these damaged cells by macrophages, causing hemolysis (destruction of red blood cells).

 

Educational Objective:

 

G6PD deficiency is associated with a decrease in the generation of reduced glutathione , leading to increased oxidative stress and susceptibility of red blood cells to damage and hemolysis.

 

Ref - Harper 31st e/p 185-186

questions.text: An elderly patient presents with an extremely painful blister characterized by a woody surface. What is the likely diagnosis? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Necrotizing fasciitis

 

The elderly patient presents with an extremely painful lower limb blister characterized by a woody surface, which is indicative of necrotizing fasciitis. Necrotizing fasciitis is a severe, rapidly progressing infection of the fascial planes that leads to tissue necrosis. It commonly affects the elderly or those with compromised immune systems and can follow trivial trauma. The infection begins in the fascia and subcutaneous tissue and can quickly spread, leading to gangrene.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Gas gangrene: This is incorrect as gas gangrene typically presents with a history of trauma or puncture wounds, and the presence of crepitus (air pockets) in the tissue, which is not described here.

 

Option B. Cellulitis: This is incorrect as cellulitis is an inflammation of the subcutaneous fat, usually without the formation of blisters or a woody texture, and it is not typically as painful as described.

 

Option D. DVT (Deep Vein Thrombosis): This is incorrect as DVT presents with limb swelling and pain but does not cause blistering or a woody surface.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Necrotizing fasciitis is a severe infection that affects the fascia and subcutaneous tissues, leading to extreme pain, blistering, and a woody surface, and requires prompt medical attention.

questions.text: A 25-year-old patient presented with dark urine, which further blackens on exposure to air. What’s the enzyme defect in this case?(NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Di Hydroxy Phenyl Acetate Dioxygenase

 

This is a case of alkaptonuria which is an inborn error in catabolism of tyrosine and phenylalanine. Enzyme deficient is Homogentisate Dioxygenase or Di-Hydroxy Phenyl Acetate Dioxygenase. The IUPAC name of homogentisate is 2,5-Dihydroxy Phenyl Acetate. The older name of this enzyme was Homogentisate oxidase. (not Homogentisate Dehydrogenase).

 

Other Options

 

Option A. Fumaryl acetoacetate hydrolase:

  • Fumaryl acetoacetate hydrolase is an enzyme involved in the breakdown of tyrosine, an amino acid. Deficiency of this enzyme leads to Tyrosinemia Type I. However, Tyrosinemia Type I does not cause darkening of urine upon exposure to air.

 

Option C. Homogentisate Dehydrogenase

  • Homogentisate oxidase, (not Homogentisate Dehydrogenase) is the enzyme responsible for the metabolism of homogentisic acid. Deficiency of this enzyme leads to Alkaptonuria. In Alkaptonuria, homogentisic acid accumulates and causes the urine to turn black upon exposure to air. This is due to the oxidation of homogentisic acid.
     

 

Option D. Phenylalanine hydroxylase:

  • Phenylalanine hydroxylase is an enzyme involved in the metabolism of phenylalanine, another amino acid. Deficiency of this enzyme leads to Phenylketonuria (PKU). PKU does not directly lead to darkening of urine upon exposure to air.

 

Educational objective:

 

In alkaptonuria patients, fresh urine is normal in color, but on standing it turns black due to oxidation of excess homogentisic acid. Homogentisic acid is an intermediate in the catabolism of Tyrosine. For complete list of phenyalanine and tyrosine catabolism defects, refer to topic aromatic amino acids.

 

Ref-Harper 31st e/pg. 286

questions.text: A 25-year-old software engineer presented with fatigue and lethargy. He worked for 12-14 hours a day, and his diet pattern consisted predominantly of fast food with very little veggies and greens. Labs: Hb - 9, MCV 106. What is the likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Folate deficiency

 

The patient presents with macrocytic anemia, indicated by an MCV of 106. Macrocytic anemia is often caused by deficiencies in vitamin B12 or folate. The patient's dietary habits, which include a diet predominantly of fast food with very little vegetables and greens, suggest a lack of dietary folate.

 

  • Vitamin B12 deficiency: Typically occurs in individuals who do not consume animal products (vegans). This deficiency is less likely in this patient due to the absence of such a dietary restriction.
  • Folate deficiency: Common in individuals with poor intake of vegetables and greens. This matches the patient's dietary pattern.
  • Iron deficiency: Results in microcytic anemia (MCV < 80), not macrocytic anemia.
  • Hemolytic anemia: Usually presents as normocytic anemia (MCV 80-100) with increased reticulocyte count and elevated LDH, which does not match the lab findings of this patient.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. B12 deficiency: While B12 deficiency causes macrocytic anemia, it is more common in individuals who avoid animal products. The patient's history does not indicate a dietary restriction on animal products.

 

Option C. Iron deficiency: Iron deficiency causes microcytic anemia (low MCV), which is not consistent with the patient's lab findings of an MCV of 106.

 

Option D. Hemolytic anemia: Hemolytic anemia typically presents with normocytic anemia and increased reticulocyte count, not with the high MCV seen in this patient.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Folate deficiency should be considered in patients with macrocytic anemia and poor dietary intake of vegetables and greens. This deficiency can cause fatigue and lethargy and is confirmed by a high MCV and dietary history.

questions.text: Which of the following activate glycogen phosphorylase? (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans A) Ca2+

 

  • Explanation: Calcium ions play a role in the activation of glycogen phosphorylase. When there is a need for energy, an increase in intracellular calcium levels can activate glycogen phosphorylase. Calcium ions bind to calmodulin, which, in turn, activates phosphorylase kinase. Phosphorylase kinase then phosphorylates and activates glycogen phosphorylase.
  • Relevance: Calcium-mediated activation of glycogen phosphorylase is part of the fight-or-flight response, ensuring a rapid release of glucose for energy during periods of stress or physical activity.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Glucose 6-Phosphate:

 

  • Explanation: Glucose 6-phosphate is a product of the glycolytic pathway and is an indicator of sufficient energy within the cell. High levels of glucose 6-phosphate inhibit glycogen phosphorylase. Glycogen phosphorylase is typically activated when glucose levels are low and energy demand is high.
  • Relevance: The presence of glucose 6-phosphate signals that the cell has adequate energy reserves and does not need to break down glycogen.

 

Option C. Glucose:

 

  • Explanation: Glucose itself does not directly activate glycogen phosphorylase. In fact, high levels of glucose can have an inhibitory effect on glycogen phosphorylase because it indicates that there is sufficient glucose available for energy needs, reducing the need to break down glycogen.
  • Relevance: Elevated glucose levels signal that there is no immediate need to activate glycogen phosphorylase.

 

Option D. High ATP (Adenosine Triphosphate):

 

  • Explanation: High levels of ATP can inhibit glycogen phosphorylase. ATP is a molecule that stores energy, and when ATP levels are high, it indicates that the cell has sufficient energy reserves. In this context, glycogen phosphorylase would not be activated to break down glycogen.
  • Relevance: High ATP levels signal that there is no immediate need for additional energy from glycogenolysis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Glycogen Phosphorylase is first and RLE of glycogenolysis. It transfers Pi, uses PLP (B6) and breaks α (1 à 4) bonds from one end until 4 glucose residues are left at branch point. End-product is Glucose 1–P (90%). It exists in two forms b and a. which is regulated by various mechanism shown as:

questions.text: Which of the following structures passing via jugular foramen has a separate canal?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Glossopharyngeal nerve

 

Explanation:

 

The glossopharyngeal nerve passing through the jugular foramen has a separate canal.

 

The glossopharyngeal nerve is the ninth cranial nerve, and it is responsible for providing sensory and motor innervation to the tongue, pharynx, and certain structures in the head and neck region. It originates in the brainstem, specifically from the medulla oblongata, and has both sensory and motor components.

 

The sensory branches of the glossopharyngeal nerve are responsible for providing sensation to the back of the tongue, tonsils, pharynx, middle ear, and the carotid sinus (which is a baroreceptor that helps regulate blood pressure). It also plays a role in taste sensation for the posterior third of the tongue.

 

The motor branches of the glossopharyngeal nerve are responsible for controlling the muscles of the pharynx and the parotid gland, which is a salivary gland located in the cheek. Dysfunction of the glossopharyngeal nerve can result in symptoms such as difficulty swallowing, decreased taste sensation, and a decreased gag reflex.

 

The glossopharyngeal nerve leaves the skull through the anteromedial part of the jugular foramen in a separate dural sheath.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hypoglossal Nerve (CN XII): The hypoglossal nerve passes through the hypoglossal canal, which is a separate opening located just anterior to the jugular foramen. This nerve controls the muscles of the tongue.

 

Option C. Vagus Nerve (CN X): The vagus nerve is another cranial nerve that passes through the jugular foramen. It does not have a separate canal within the jugular foramen. The vagus nerve has numerous functions, including control of the heart, lungs, and digestive organs.

 

Option D. Accessory Nerve (CN XI): The accessory nerve enters the jugular foramen alongside the vagus and glossopharyngeal nerves. It also does not have a separate canal within the jugular foramen. This nerve controls the sternocleidomastoid and trapezius muscles.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The glossopharyngeal nerve is unique among the nerves passing through the jugular foramen as it occupies a separate canal. Understanding this anatomical detail is vital for surgical navigation and for diagnosing nerve pathologies that may affect swallowing, taste, and autonomic functions in the neck and head region.

questions.text: A 60-year-old male presents to the emergency department with chest discomfort and dyspnea. A diagnosis of cardiac tamponade is considered. Which of the following changes in jugular venous pressure (JVP) is most indicative of cardiac tamponade? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Y descent is blunted/absent

 

Y descent is blunted/absent: Correct. In cardiac tamponade, the pressure within the pericardium limits the right ventricular filling during diastole, which blunts or abolishes the Y descent on the JVP waveform, as it reflects the rapid emptying of the jugular veins into the right atrium.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Prominent X descent: Incorrect. The X descent represents atrial relaxation and downward displacement of the closed tricuspid valve during ventricular systole. It can be prominent in conditions such as constrictive pericarditis but is not specifically indicative of cardiac tamponade.

 

Option C. Large a waves: Incorrect. Large a waves are associated with increased resistance to right atrial emptying, as seen in tricuspid stenosis or right atrial hypertrophy, not typically in cardiac tamponade.

 

Option D. Steep Y descent: Incorrect. A steep Y descent is associated with conditions that allow rapid venous filling into the right ventricle, such as constrictive pericarditis, and is not characteristic of cardiac tamponade.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cardiac tamponade, the Y descent on the jugular venous pressure waveform is blunted or absent due to restricted right ventricular filling during diastole.

questions.text: A 58-year-old hypertensive patient with a history of myocardial infarction (MI) presents with an acute attack of migraine. Which of the following medications should not be given? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Sumatriptan

 

Sumatriptan is a medication used to treat acute migraine attacks and works as a selective serotonin receptor agonist (5-HT1B/1D receptor agonist). However, it is contraindicated in patients with a history of coronary artery disease (CAD) or other significant cardiovascular diseases, including previous myocardial infarction (MI). This is because sumatriptan can cause vasoconstriction, which can exacerbate these conditions, leading to serious cardiovascular events.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ibuprofen:  A nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug (NSAID) that can be used to treat migraine pain. It does not have the same cardiovascular risks as triptans and can be safely used in patients with a history of MI, although caution is advised in hypertensive patients.

 

Option C. Propranolol:  A beta-blocker often used for migraine prophylaxis. It is actually beneficial for patients with a history of MI as it reduces the risk of further cardiac events by lowering heart rate and blood pressure.

 

Option D. Verapamil: A calcium channel blocker that is sometimes used for migraine prevention. It is generally safe for use in patients with a history of MI and can help manage hypertension as well.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Sumatriptan, a vasoconstrictor, should not be given to patients with a history of coronary artery disease or myocardial infarction due to the risk of triggering serious cardiovascular events.

questions.text: In which of the following locations does meiosis normally occur in the human body? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Adult ovary

 

Meiosis occurs in the adult ovary.

 

  • Meiosis is the process by which gametes (sperm and eggs) are produced in sexually reproducing organisms.
  • It occurs only in germ cells and leads to the formation of haploid gametes.
  • To reduce the number of chromosomes to the haploid number of 23, meiosis requires two cell divisions, meiosis I and meiosis II.
  • In females, meiosis occurs in the ovaries during fetal development, but is arrested in prophase I until puberty.
  • After puberty, meiosis resumes and one ovum is produced each month.
  • In males, meiosis occurs in the testes and produces sperm.
  • Meiosis in the testes begins during puberty and continues throughout adulthood.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Adrenal: The adrenal glands are located atop each kidney and are involved in the production of various hormones, such as cortisol, aldosterone, and sex steroids. Meiosis, the process by which germ cells divide to produce gametes with half the number of chromosomes, does not occur in the adrenal glands. Instead, the adrenal glands are involved in steroidogenesis or the production of steroid hormones.

 

Option C. Prepubertal testis: The testes are the male reproductive organs that produce spermatozoa (sperm cells) and testosterone. In males, meiosis begins during puberty. In the prepubertal testis, the germ cells are not yet undergoing meiosis to form mature sperm cells. These germ cells (spermatogonia) proliferate by mitosis during childhood but only enter meiosis to become spermatocytes and eventually mature spermatozoa after the onset of puberty.

 

Option D. Hypothalamus: It is a region of the brain responsible for various vital functions, including the release of hormones that regulate the pituitary gland. It is not involved in meiosis. Instead, it plays an essential role in regulating various physiological processes, such as body temperature, thirst, hunger, and circadian rhythms. It also plays a significant role in controlling the release of hormones from the anterior pituitary by producing releasing or inhibiting hormones.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Adult ovaries are responsible for producing ova (egg cells) and hormones such as estrogen and progesterone. Meiosis begins in the fetal ovaries but is arrested in prophase I until puberty.

 

After puberty, with each menstrual cycle, some oocytes resume meiosis, completing meiosis I and arresting in meiosis II. It's only after fertilization that meiosis II completes. Therefore, meiosis occurs in the adult ovary as it is essential for the formation of mature ova or egg cells.

questions.text: In which condition is pupillary light reaction absent and accommodation reaction present? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Neurosyphilis

 

Explanation:

 

The condition described is characteristic of the Argyll Robertson pupil, which is associated with neurosyphilis. In this condition, the pupillary light reflex is absent, meaning the pupils do not constrict in response to light. However, the accommodation reflex, which involves pupil constriction when focusing on a near object, is preserved. This phenomenon is often summarized by the -

 

Mnemonic "ARP and PRA" (Accommodation Reflex Present and Pupillary Reflex Absent).

 

 

 

The underlying mechanism involves damage to the interneurons in the pretectal area of the midbrain, which affects the light reflex pathway while sparing the accommodation pathway.

 

The Near triad, consisting of accommodation, convergence, and miosis, remains intact in neurosyphilis, explaining why accommodation is preserved.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Horner’s syndrome: This condition is characterized by ptosis, miosis, and anhidrosis due to a disruption in the sympathetic pathways. The pupillary light reaction is not typically absent.

 

Option C. Papilledema: This condition involves swelling of the optic disc due to increased intracranial pressure. The pupillary light reaction is usually normal in papilledema.

 

Option D. Optic neuritis: This inflammation of the optic nerve often leads to a relative afferent pupillary defect (RAPD) or Marcus Gunn pupil, where the affected eye shows a reduced direct response to light. However, the accommodation reaction is not selectively preserved as described.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Argyll Robertson pupil, associated with neurosyphilis, presents with absent pupillary light reaction and preserved accommodation reaction, highlighting a distinctive neuro-ophthalmologic sign of this condition.

questions.text: If any unsound minded person commits any crime unconsciously it won't be considered as a punishable offence. This is defined by which of the following law? (FMGE JAN 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Mc Naughten's rule

 

(84 IPC) Mc Naughten's rule “Nothing is an offence which is done by a person who, at the time of doing it, by reason of unsoundness of mind, is incapable of knowing the nature of the act, or that he is doing what is either wrong or contrary to law.”

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Curren’s Rule states that an accused person is NOT responsible if at the time of act, he didn’t have the capacity to conform to requirements of law (psychopathy, sociopathy).

 

Option B. Durham’s Rule - An accused is NOT responsible if his unlawful act is a product of mental disease or defect.

 

Option D. Locard’s principle of exchange – whenever two objects come in contact there is exchange of physical evidence. This concept is used to detect crimes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

McNaughten's rule provides the legal framework for the insanity defense, asserting that an individual who commits a crime while being incapable of understanding the nature or wrongfulness of their actions due to unsoundness of mind cannot be held criminally responsible.

questions.text: A child presented with leukocoria and an intraocular mass, which on histopathological examination had the presence of Flexner-Wintersteiner rosettes. Which of the following is the likely diagnosis in the child? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Retinoblastoma

 

Retinoblastoma is the most common primary intraocular malignancy in children. The classical presentation includes leukocoria (white pupillary reflex) and an intraocular mass. Histopathologically, the presence of Flexner-Wintersteiner rosettes is a key diagnostic feature of retinoblastoma. These rosettes are true rosettes characterized by a circular arrangement of tumor cells around an empty lumen, resembling a flower.

 

In this case:

 

  • Leukocoria is a typical clinical presentation of retinoblastoma.
  • The intraocular mass in a child further supports this diagnosis.
  • The presence of Flexner-Wintersteiner rosettes confirms the diagnosis, as they are pathognomonic for retinoblastoma.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Melanoma: While melanoma can occur in the eye, it is more common in adults and typically does not present with leukocoria or Flexner-Wintersteiner rosettes.

 

Option B. Lymphoma: Intraocular lymphoma is rare in children and typically presents differently, without the characteristic rosettes seen in retinoblastoma.

 

Option D. Squamous cell carcinoma: This malignancy affects the ocular surface and is not typically associated with intraocular masses or leukocoria. It also lacks the histological pattern of Flexner-Wintersteiner rosettes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Retinoblastoma is identified by leukocoria, an intraocular mass in children, and the presence of Flexner-Wintersteiner rosettes on histopathology, which are true rosettes specific to this diagnosis.

choices.text: Wait for an hour for spontaneous labor

questions.text: You are examining a multigravida in the second stage of labor for the past two hours. On examination, contractions are adequate, the cervix is fully dilated with the head at station 0 with molding 2+ and caput 2+. The sagittal suture is in the right occipito-transverse position. The fetal heart rate is 140 beats/minute. Which of the following is carried out for the management of this patient? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Lower segment cesarean section

 

  • The given clinical scenario points to a diagnosis of deep transverse arrest (DTA)
  • There are features of CPD (Caput 2 + and moulding 2+)
  • Hence, a lower segment cesarean section is carried out for the management of this patient.
  • In deep transverse arrest
    • The sagittal suture is placed in the transverse bispinous diameter.
    • There is no descent of the head despite good uterine contractions
    • The cervix is fully dilated
    • If the pelvis is adequate, application of ventouse or manual rotation and forces application can be tried. (Vacuum is preferred)
    • If signs of CDP/ obstruction: Cesarean section is done

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mid pelvic forceps: Mid pelvic forceps: Cannot be applied in this scenario as there are features of obstructed labor with deep transverse arrest

 

Option B. Vacuum-assisted delivery: Vacuum is an option in deep transverse arrest but only if there is no CPD. With caput ++ and moulding ++, there is likely an element of CPD and obstruction and hence vacuum should not be used

 

Option C. Wait for an hour for spontaneous labor: Waiting and watching is not an option as the patient is already showing features of obstructed labor and she has already been in 2nd stage of labor for 2 hours (upper limit for 2nd stage of labor in primi is 3h and in multi is 2h)

 

Educational Objective:

 

In a case of deep transverse arrest with features of CPD, a lower segment cesarean section is the appropriate management to prevent complications and ensure safe delivery.

 

Ref: Page 661, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics, 8th edition

questions.text: A 6-year-old child with a previous history of GTCS presents with convulsions which are ongoing since 45 minutes. What should be the appropriate management of this patient? (Fmge Jan 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Lorazepam followed by levetiracetam.

 

In the case of a prolonged seizure such as status epilepticus, immediate seizure termination is critical. Lorazepam is a preferred initial treatment due to its rapid onset of action in stopping seizures. After the acute phase is managed, levetiracetam can be used for ongoing seizure control. This combination makes option (a) the most appropriate choice for the described scenario.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Valproate followed by Gabapentin: Valproate is an effective antiepileptic drug, but it's not typically the first choice for acute seizure termination in the emergency setting of status epilepticus. Gabapentin is used as a maintenance therapy for seizures but not in the acute setting.

 

Option C. Ethosuximide followed by Gabapentin: Ethosuximide is used primarily for absence seizures and is not appropriate in the acute management of status epilepticus. Gabapentin, as mentioned, is for maintenance therapy.

 

Option D. Carbamazepine followed by Gabapentin: Carbamazepine is used for the treatment of epilepsy but is not the drug of choice in the acute management of status epilepticus. Gabapentin, again, is for longer-term control.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Lorazepam is a benzodiazepine and is one of the first-line treatments for the acute management of seizures, particularly in status epilepticus. Following the control of immediate seizures with lorazepam, levetiracetam can be used as maintenance antiepileptic therapy.

choices.text: Topical antibiotics and decongestants for 4 weeks
IV antibiotics and follow up after a month

questions.text: A child presents with foul-smelling ear discharge. On further exploration, a small perforation is found in the pars flaccida of the tympanic membrane as shown below. Most appropriate management would be: (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Tympanomastoid exploration

 

The child presents with foul-smelling ear discharge and a small perforation in the pars flaccida of the tympanic membrane, indicating an attic perforation. This condition is consistent with attico-antral chronic suppurative otitis media (CSOM), also known as unsafe CSOM. This type of CSOM is characterized by scanty, mucopurulent, foul-smelling discharge, which may sometimes be bloodstained.

 

The definitive management for attico-antral CSOM is tympanomastoid exploration. This procedure helps to eradicate the disease from the middle ear and mastoid, preventing further complications such as cholesteatoma and hearing loss.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Topical antibiotics and decongestants for 4 weeks: While topical antibiotics can be used to manage the discharge and infection initially, they are not the definitive treatment for attico-antral CSOM. The primary goal is to control the infection, but definitive surgical intervention is required for complete management.

 

Option B. IV antibiotics and follow up after a month: IV antibiotics may be used in severe cases to control acute infection, but they are not the standard approach for managing attico-antral CSOM. Follow-up after a month without addressing the underlying condition is not adequate.

 

Option C. Tympanoplasty: Tympanoplasty is a surgical procedure aimed at repairing the tympanic membrane and is typically used in cases of safe CSOM or tubotympanic CSOM. It is not appropriate for attico-antral CSOM, where more extensive surgical intervention is required.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Attico-antral CSOM, characterized by foul-smelling discharge and attic perforation, requires tympanomastoid exploration for definitive management.

questions.text: A public health researcher is analyzing demographic patterns in a tribal region of Jharkhand, India. The community has high birth and death rates due to limited healthcare and high disease prevalence. In which stage of the demographic transition model is the birth rate typically the highest?  (FMGE JAN 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Stage 1

 

The highest birth rate is observed in Stage 1 of the demographic cycle, characterized by both high birth and high death rates due to limited healthcare and high disease prevalence.

 

Five stages of the demographic cycle: -

 

Stage 1: (High Stationary): High Birth Rate & High Death Rate

 

Stage 2: (Early Expanding): Birth Rate Unchanged & Death Rate Decrease

 

Stage3: (Late Expanding): Birth Rate: Decreases & Death Rate: Decreases

 

Stage 4: (Late Stationary): BR: Low & DR: Low

 

Stage 5: (Declining): BR < DR/Population Decreases

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Five stages of demographic cycle

questions.text: Identify the deficiency: (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Vitamin D

 

RICKETS

 

  • In rickets, maturation of osteoid occurs before closure of growth plates, which superimposes the skeletal growth abnormalities i.e., incomplete skeletal calcification and softening of bones.
  • Pathology:
    • Irregular laying of osteoid with widening of osteoid seam and islets into the diaphysis
    • Thin and weak new trabeculae
    • On joint loading, juxta-epiphyseal metaphysis becomes broad and cup-shaped

 

 

  • Causes:
    • Vitamin D disorders: nutritional, secondary, malabsorption, decreased liver (25) hydroxylase activity
    • Calcium deficiency
    • Phosphorus deficiency
    • Renal losses: Fanconi syndrome
    • Tumors associated with rickets: GCT, osteoblastoma, fibrous dysplasia, neurofibromatosis
       
  • Radiographic findings:
    • The characteristic feature of rickets are thickening and widening of growth plate (physis).
    • Indistinct and hazy metaphysis abnormally wide (splaying) with cupping or flaring (Brush-like appearance)
    • Bowing of diaphysis, with thinning of cortices
    • Looser’s zone in 20% cases

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Vitamin C. Scurvy is a condition caused by dietary lack of vitamin C (ascorbic acid), hence is also called hypovitaminosis C. It is characterized by an increased bleeding tendency, impaired collagen synthesis resulting in osteoporosis, and impaired wound healing. It is rarely seen in adults. Young children and elderly are more predisposed to scurvy due to diet or overheating of food. It does not occur before 6 months of age. Patients present with lethargy, malaise, bone pain, bleeding diathesis, and impaired wound healing. Pediatric radiographic features include generalized osteopenia, cortical thinning (pencil-point cortex), periosteal reaction due to subperiosteal hemorrhage, expansion of costochondral junctions (scorbutic rosary), hemarthrosis, Wimberger ring sign (circular, opaque shadow around epiphyseal centers of ossification, due to bleeding).

 

 

Option C. Vitamin A. Hypovitaminosis A results from inadequate intake of vitamin A, fat malabsorption, or liver disorders and produces a variety of epithelial alterations. Radiographic features includes slow bone development, widening of cranial sutures with bulging fontanelles, and skull hyperostosis.

 

Option D. Vitamin E. Hypovitaminosis E is rare. It is usually due to the malabsorption of vitamin E, e.g. cystic fibrosis or pancreatic failure. It manifests as dysfunction of the CNS, characteristically presenting with a tremor and ataxia. Tendon reflexes are often absent. Clinically and radiologically it may be indistinguishable from the neurological sequelae of hypovitaminosis B12, i.e. subacute combined degeneration of the cord (SACD).

 

Educational Objective:

 

Vitamin D deficiency presents as thickening and widening of growth plate (physis); indistinct and hazy metaphysis with abnormally wide (splaying), cupping or flaring (Brush-like) appearance; and bowing of diaphysis, with thinning of cortices.

questions.text: Superior gluteal nerve supplies all of the following structures except:(INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Piriformis

 

All of the structures except pyriformis are supplied by the superior gluteal nerve. Pyriformis is supplied by the nerve to the piriformis.

 

The superior gluteal nerve is a nerve that originates from the dorsal branches of the L4, L5, and S1 spinal nerves. It exits the pelvis through the greater sciatic foramen above the piriformis muscle and provides motor innervation to the gluteus medius, gluteus minimus, and tensor fasciae latae muscles. The superior gluteal vessels also accompany the nerve.

 

The nerve to the piriformis, on the other hand, arises from the dorsal branches of the S1 and S2 spinal nerves. It passes through or underneath the piriformis muscle and provides motor innervation to the piriformis muscle itself.

 

Damage or compression to the superior gluteal nerve can result in weakness or atrophy of the gluteus medius, gluteus minimus, and tensor fasciae latae muscles, leading to difficulty with hip abduction and stabilization. Compression of the nerve to the piriformis can result in piriformis syndrome, a condition in which the piriformis muscle irritates or compresses the nerve, causing pain and numbness in the buttock and leg.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Gluteus medius: The superior gluteal nerve supplies the gluteus medius muscle. This muscle is important for hip abduction and stabilization of the hip joint, especially during activities like walking and running.

 

Option B. Gluteus minimus: Similar to the gluteus medius, the superior gluteal nerve also supplies the gluteus minimus muscle. This muscle is located deep to the gluteus medius and assists in hip abduction and stabilization.

 

Option D. Tensor fasciae latae: The superior gluteal nerve supplies the tensor fasciae latae muscle. This muscle helps in flexing, abducting, and medially rotating the hip joint. It also assists in stabilizing the pelvis when standing on one leg.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The piriformis muscle is not supplied by the superior gluteal nerve. Instead, it is primarily innervated by the branches of the sacral plexus, specifically the ventral rami of S1 and S2. The piriformis muscle plays a role in external hip rotation.

questions.text: What among the following can be employed for establishing the confidence interval in the Kaplan-Meier survival curve? [INICET MAY 2023]
questions.solution:
Ans. (d) Hall-Wellner Band

 

  • The Kaplan-Meier survival curve is a graphical representation commonly used in survival analysis to display the probability of an event, typically survival, over time.
  • It is particularly useful when studying the time to a specific event, such as death or disease progression.
  • The Kaplan-Meier curve often incorporates bands around the survival estimate, which represent the confidence interval.
  • Hall-Wellner bands, Gill bands, and Nair's Equal Precision confidence bands are used for this purpose.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Unequal precision band: Not a standard term used for Kaplan-Meier survival curves.

 

Option B. Hirshberg band: Not a recognized method for establishing confidence intervals in Kaplan-Meier survival curves.

 

Option C. Holmes band: Not a recognized method for establishing confidence intervals in Kaplan-Meier survival curves.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The Hall-Wellner band is employed for establishing the confidence interval in the Kaplan-Meier survival curve, providing a visual representation of the variability and confidence in the survival estimates.

questions.text: A 21-year-old female was brought dead to the casualty. On examination there was frothing from her nose and mouth. What is the likely cause of death? (INICET NOVEMBER 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Drowning

 

The image shows frothing from nostrils which is likely to be due to drowning.

 

Postmortem changes of drowning:

 

  • Bloody froth in the airway

  • Water in the stomach and small intestine

  • Water in middle ear

  • Cerebral edema

  • Bloated and cyanosed face

  • Petrous or mastoid hemorrhage.

  • Voluminous / ballooned out lungs

  • Suffused conjunctive, dilated pupils

  • "Washerwoman" changes of the hands (shriveling of the skin) develop when submerged in water for several hours

  • Cutis anserina / goose skin- The contraction of the erector pilorum muscles causes puckering and a grainy appearance of the skin.

  • Cadaveric spasm - Gravel, weed, soil, grass, etc. is firmly held in the clenched hands due to cadaveric spasm. This is a vital sign of antemortem drowning.

  • Rigor mortis - This appears early in cases of a violent antemortem struggle.

  • Diatom test

 

Gettler test can be done to estimate the chloride content in the right and left sides of the heart to differentiate between freshwater and saltwater drowning.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Hanging: Typically presents with a ligature mark around the neck, not frothing.

 

Option C. Strangulation: Often shows signs of external trauma to the neck, such as bruising or fractures, but not frothing.

 

Option D. Traumatic asphyxia: This results from severe chest compression, leading to petechiae and cyanosis but not usually frothing from the nose and mouth.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Frothing from the nose and mouth, along with other specific postmortem findings, strongly suggests drowning as the cause of death.

questions.text: A man lives with his pregnant wife and a child under 3 years old. His brother and his wife are staying with them for a month. How should this family be categorized? (FMGE JAN 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Nuclear family

 

A nuclear family, also known as an elementary or unitary family, consists of a married couple and their children who are still regarded as dependents. In this scenario, the core members are the man, his pregnant wife, and their young child, fitting the definition of a nuclear family.

 

Even though the man's brother and his wife are temporarily staying with them, this does not change the fundamental structure of the family. The temporary presence of additional relatives does not convert a nuclear family into an extended or joint family unless these additional members become permanent residents and contribute to the common household in a sustained manner.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Extended family: An extended family includes additional relatives living together permanently. In this case, the brother and his wife are not permanent residents.

 

Option C. Joint family: A joint family consists of multiple married couples and their children living together permanently, holding property in common, and typically being managed by the senior male member. This structure includes familial relations that enjoy primacy over marital relations, which is not applicable here due to the temporary nature of the brother’s stay.

 

Option D. Third generation: A three-generation family includes representatives from three generations living together in one household. This scenario does not include a third generation (e.g., grandparents).

 

Educational Objective:

 

A nuclear family consists of parents and their children, even if other relatives are temporarily staying with them.

questions.text: Boundaries of Calot triangle are formed by all except? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Gall bladder

 

The gallbladder itself does not form a boundary of Calot's triangle. Instead, it's closely related to the triangle, being situated just adjacent to it.

 

It's an important landmark in cholecystectomy (surgical removal of the gallbladder) because of the structures that it contains. The identification of this triangle helps to prevent injury to the common bile duct during surgery.

 

  • Boundaries of Calot's triangle is bounded:
    • Medially/Left side - Common hepatic duct
    • Right side/ Laterally   Cystic duct
    • Superior - lower surface of liver
    • Contents of calot’s triangle - Cystic artery and lymph node of lund 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Common hepatic duct: This forms the inferior boundary of Calot's triangle. The common hepatic duct is the duct formed by the joining of the left and right hepatic ducts. It later joins the cystic duct to form the common bile duct.

 

Option B. Cystic duct: This duct connects the gallbladder to the common hepatic duct and subsequently forms the common bile duct. The cystic duct forms the lateral boundary of Calot's triangle.

 

Option C. Cystic artery: Inferior surface of liver forms the superior boundary of calot’s triangle

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hepatocystic triangle and triangle of Calot - Hepatocystic triangle (blue): Upper boundary of hepatocystic triangle is the inferior border of liver. Lateral, the cystic duct and the neck of the gallbladder. Medial, the common hepatic duct.

questions.text: Which among the following indicates severe COVID-19 ? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) SpO2 < 85% on room air


Severe COVID-19 is characterized by a significant drop in oxygen saturation. An SpO2 of less than 85% on room air indicates severe hypoxemia.

 

Any SpO2 of less than 90% indicate severe COVID and 90-93% indicates moderate COVID

 

Other Options:
 

Option A. RR >24/min: Indicates moderate, not severe, COVID-19. RR>30/min indicate severe COVID
 

Option B. MAP 70 mmHg: Does not specifically indicate severe COVID-19. Hemodynamic instability i.e. MAP <65 OR 65 or above with vasopressors indicates severe COVID. 
 

Option C. Lung infiltrates >42% on CT: Not a specific criterion for COVID-19 severity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Severe COVID-19 is indicated by an SpO2 of less than 85% on room air.

questions.text: Which pathogen causes attachment-effacement lesion in the intestinal mucosa? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Enteropathogenic Escherichia coli


Attaching-and-effacing is the “hallmark” of the EPEC infections, a lesion that is characterized by the intimate attachment of the bacteria to the host epithelial cell membrane and the effacement of the microvilli. This mechanism is a hallmark of EPEC infections, leading to copious watery diarrhea, especially in infants.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Enterotoxigenic Escherichia coli (ETEC): Incorrect: ETEC causes watery diarrhea through the production of enterotoxins that increase cyclic AMP (cAMP) or cyclic GMP (cGMP) levels, leading to fluid and electrolyte loss. It does not cause attachment-effacement lesions.

 

Option C. Enteroinvasive Escherichia coli (EIEC): Incorrect: EIEC invades and destroys epithelial cells lining the colon, leading to fever, cramping, watery diarrhea, and dysentery with scant, bloody stools. It does not cause attachment-effacement lesions.

 

Option D. Diffusely adherent Escherichia coli (DAEC): Incorrect: DAEC is known for its diffuse adherence pattern to epithelial cells, causing persistent diarrhea in children. It does not cause attachment-effacement lesions.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A man with diabetes was on medication and forgot to take his meals before going to the gym. During his workout, he collapsed, and his blood sugar level was found to be 50 mg/dL. Which of the following oral antidiabetic drugs can result in hypoglycemia when used as monotherapy? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Glimepiride

 

Glimepiride is a sulfonylurea, a class of drugs that stimulate the pancreas to release more insulin. This increased insulin release can lower blood glucose levels significantly, leading to hypoglycemia, especially if meals are skipped or physical activity is increased. Sulfonylureas are well known for their potential to cause hypoglycemia when used as monotherapy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Metformin: This drug primarily decreases hepatic glucose production and increases insulin sensitivity. It rarely causes hypoglycemia when used alone because it does not directly stimulate insulin release.

 

Option C. Acarbose:  An alpha-glucosidase inhibitor that slows carbohydrate absorption in the intestine. It does not cause hypoglycemia when used alone, as it does not affect insulin secretion.

 

Option D. Dapagliflozin:  A sodium-glucose co-transporter 2 (SGLT2) inhibitor that promotes glucose excretion in the urine. It has a low risk of causing hypoglycemia when used as monotherapy because it does not increase insulin levels.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Group of drugs that tend to produce hypoglycemia when used as monotherapy:

 

  • Insulin
  • Secretagogues: Sulfonylureas, such as glimepiride, can cause hypoglycemia when used as monotherapy due to their mechanism of increasing insulin release from the pancreas.

choices.text: Primary sclerosing cholangitis

questions.text: Cholangiocarcinoma is not a complication of?  (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Hepatitis B

 

Cholangiocarcinoma is a cancer that forms in the bile ducts. It is associated with various risk factors and conditions, but Hepatitis B is not directly linked to its development. Hepatitis B virus (HBV) is primarily associated with hepatocellular carcinoma, which is a different type of liver cancer. The other options listed are known risk factors for cholangiocarcinoma.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Opisthorchis: This parasitic infection is a known risk factor for cholangiocarcinoma. 

 

Option B. Primary sclerosing cholangitis: This chronic liver disease involving inflammation and scarring of the bile ducts is a significant risk factor for developing cholangiocarcinoma.

 

Option C. Caroli's disease: This congenital disorder characterized by cystic dilatation of intrahepatic bile ducts increases the risk of cholangiocarcinoma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hepatitis B virus primarily causes hepatocellular carcinoma, not cholangiocarcinoma, unlike other liver conditions such as parasitic infections, primary sclerosing cholangitis, and Caroli's disease.

choices.text: Follows autosomal dominant mode of inheritance

questions.text: Which of the following is not true regarding ataxia-telangiectasia? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Follows autosomal dominant mode inheritance

 

The mode of inheritance in ataxia-telangiectasia is autosomal recessive.

 

Ataxia telangiectasia:

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ataxia-telangiectasia is an autosomal recessive disorder caused by mutations in the ATM gene on chromosome 11, characterized by defective DNA repair, immunodeficiency, progressive neurological degeneration, and increased risk of malignancies.

questions.text: Which of the following helps in bacterial adhesion? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Fimbriae

 

Fimbriae help in bacterial adhesion.

 

Fimbriae, also called pili are hair-like surface appendage that projects from the cell surface as straight filaments. Fimbriae are classified based on the function as ordinary pili and sex pili.

 

Functions of pili:

 

  • Bacterial adhesion of symbiotic and pathogenic bacteria to host cells using adhesins.
  • Resistance to phagocytosis.
  • Antigenic pilin proteins are responsible for the immune response.
  • Twitching motility to bacteria.
  • Bacterial conjugation through sex pili, which transfer of genetic material occurs.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cytoplasmic membrane: While important for many cellular functions, the cytoplasmic membrane itself is not typically involved in adhesion.

 

Option B. Mesosomes: These are folded invaginations in the bacterial membrane thought to be artifacts of cell preparation and not involved in adhesion.

 

Option D. Lipopolysaccharides (LPS): Found in the outer membrane of Gram-negative bacteria, LPS can play a role in interactions with the host immune system but are not primarily responsible for adhesion.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Fimbriae are essential bacterial structures for adhesion, enabling bacteria to attach to host cells and surfaces, crucial for initiating infections and forming biofilms. This key role makes them important targets for strategies to prevent and treat bacterial infections.

questions.text: A 60-year-old shipyard worker presents with increasing shortness of breath and a persistent dry cough over the past year. He has worked with insulation materials for 35 years. Physical examination reveals diminished breath sounds bilaterally. A chest X-ray reveals a "ground glass" appearance. Which of the following conditions is most consistent with these findings? (FMGE JAN 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Asbestosis

 

Ground glass appearance on chest x ray is seen in asbestosis. In silicosis, on chest X-ray we get Nodular fibrosis and snow storm appearance.

 

Asbestosis

 

  • Asbestosis is a pneumoconiosis that occurs due to: Exposure to asbestos dust. Asbestosis does not usually appear until after 5-10 years of exposure
  • Sputum shows ‘asbestos bodies’, which are asbestos fibres coated with fibrin.
  • Asbestos may lead to pulmonary fibrosis, carcinoma of bronchus, mesothelioma of peritoneum/ pleura and cancer of GIT.
  • Asbestos type most dangerous is ‘amphibole’.

 

Other Options: 

 

 

Bagassosis: An allergic response to the inhalation of moldy bagasse, which is sugarcane fiber residue. Bagasse dust blocks bronchioles thus leading to bronchitis and bronchopneumonia. It has been shown to be due to Thermoactinomyces sacchari. Prevention and Bagasse control measures are Keeping the moisture content > 20% and Spraying bagasse with 2% propionic acid (fungicide). 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Asbestosis is associated with a "ground glass" appearance on chest X-ray and occurs in workers exposed to asbestos over long periods.

questions.text: The green line corresponds to which vertebral level? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. L5

 

Explanation:

 

The green line marked on the torso corresponds to the L5 vertebral level. This line is also known as the intertubercular plane or Tuffier's line, which is anatomically aligned with the upper border of the L5 vertebra. The intertubercular plane is significant in clinical settings as it passes through the highest points of the iliac crests, located at the L4-L5 intervertebral disc space. This reference point is crucial for procedures such as spinal anesthesia and lumbar punctures, where accurate identification of vertebral levels is essential.

 

Clinical Significance:

 

  • It serves as a reference point for various medical procedures, particularly those involving the lumbar spine, spinal anesthesia, and the placement of lumbar punctures (spinal taps).
  • When performing a lumbar puncture, healthcare providers often use the intertubercular plane as a landmark to identify the appropriate level for inserting the needle into the subarachnoid space.
    • Tuffier's Line: The term "Tuffier's line" is often used interchangeably with the intertubercular plane. Dr. Paul Tuffier, a French surgeon, introduced this reference point in the early 20th century.
    • Variations: It's important to note that individual anatomical variations exist, and the level of the iliac crests can vary among individuals. Therefore, healthcare providers may use additional methods, such as palpation of bony landmarks or radiological guidance, to accurately identify the L4-L5 intervertebral space.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. T12: Incorrect as it corresponds to the lower end of the thoracic spine.

 

Option C. L1: Incorrect and typically aligns with the lower border of the first lumbar vertebra.

 

Option D. L3: Incorrect as it corresponds to the subcostal plane, not the intertubercular plane.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Abdominal Planes & Quadrants –

 

 

#2 Horizontal Plane -

  • Subcostal Plane (L3)
  • Trans tubercular Plane (L5- upper border)

#2 Vertical Planes

Midclavicular Line / Plane (from midpoint of clavicle till midinguinal point)

  • Trans-pyloric Plane of Addison - Lower border of L1

Supracristal Plane - L4

questions.text: A woman with right-sided loss of sensations of both the upper and lower limb complains of shooting pain from her fingers to the right shoulder and a burning sensation when touching cold water. Motor functions are normal. Which of the following structures is likely to be involved? (INICET May 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Thalamus

 

The given clinical stem of a hemi-sensory loss and severe excruciating pain of the affected areas is suggestive of thalamic pain syndrome also known as Dejerine Roussy syndrome. Hence, thalamus marked as B is most likely to be involved.

 

The thalamus is a paired structure, with one thalamus on each side of the brain. It relays sensory and motor signals to the cerebral cortex and regulates consciousness, sleep, and alertness. The thalamus has multiple nuclei, each serving different functions. The ventral posterior nucleus, for instance, is vital for relaying somatosensory information. If the thalamus is damaged, it can lead to loss of sensation, and in certain cases, even cause the burning, shooting pain and abnormal temperature sensations described in the scenario, which aligns with the symptoms of thalamic syndrome.

 

 

The structures marked in the image are:

 

Option A.  A- Internal capsule

 

Option B. B- Thalamus

 

Option C. C- Subthalamic nucleus

 

Option D. D- Substantia nigra

 

Lesion in other three structures will lead to motor deficit and in question it is clearly mentioned that there is no motor deficit, only sensory deficit is the which  clearly indicates that the lesion lies in thalamus.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Internal capsule: The internal capsule is a bundle of white matter fibers that separates the caudate nucleus and the thalamus from the lenticular nucleus (putamen and globus pallidus). The anterior limb separates the head of the caudate from the lenticular nucleus, while the posterior limb separates the thalamus from the lenticular nucleus. It contains ascending and descending axonal fibers running between the cerebral cortex and the brainstem/spinal cord. Damage to the internal capsule, especially its posterior limb, can cause contralateral hemiparesis or hemiplegia (motor deficits). However, the woman's motor functions are described as normal, making this a less likely option given the scenario.

 

Option C. Subthalamic nucleus: The subthalamic nucleus is part of the basal ganglia circuit and is specifically associated with motor function. Lesions of the subthalamic nucleus, particularly on one side, might result in hemiballismus, which is characterized by violent, flinging movements of the contralateral limbs. It is not typically associated with sensory disturbances, or the pain described in the scenario.

 

Option D. Substantia nigra: The substantia nigra is in the midbrain and plays a critical role in reward, addiction, and movement. It contains dopamine-producing neurons. The degeneration of these neurons is a hallmark of Parkinson's disease. Lesions in the substantia nigra would primarily produce motor symptoms, such as rigidity, bradykinesia, and tremors. It would not typically lead to the sensory disturbances described in the scenario.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The thalamic pain syndrome is caused by the occlusion of these thalamic and thalamogeniculate branches. C/L hemisensory loss, which begins as numbness and escalates to cause intense burning pain in the affected areas, is what distinguishes it.

 

A thalamic lesion results in a breakdown in communication between the brain's afferent route and cortex because the thalamus serves as the site for the relay of sensory information between the periphery and cortex. The healing process following a thalamic infarct is painful.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman is bitten by a stray dog. She had received post-exposure prophylaxis for a monkey bite two months ago. What is the appropriate management for her current rabies exposure? (FMGE JAN 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Wound care + IM vaccine 0,3

 

As patient has already received post-exposure prophylaxis for monkey bite, she should receive Re-exposure prophylaxis in the form of 2 doses of vaccine on days 0 & 3 along with wound care.

 

Post-Exposure Prophylaxis (PEP)

 

Wound Care - Immediate care 

 

Thorough washing and flushing of the wound for approximately 15 minutes, with soap or detergent and copious amounts of water, is required; Where available, an iodine-containing, or similarly viricidal, topical preparation should be applied to the wound

 

WHO Rabies Exposure Categories

 

  • Category I: Touching or feeding animals, animal licks on intact skin (no exposure)
  • Category II: Nibbling of uncovered skin, minor scratches or abrasions without bleeding (exposure)
  • Category III: Single or multiple transdermal bites or scratches, contamination of mucous membrane or broken skin with saliva from animal licks, exposures due to direct contact with bats (severe exposure)

 

PEP Recommendations

 

 

Additional Information

 

Rabies Immunoglobulin (RIG) Administration

 

  • There are 2 types of RIG available for passive immunisation: human rabies immunoglobulin (hRIG) and equine rabies immunoglobulin (eRIG). Both hRIG and eRIG are equally effective and safe. But eRIG is less costly than hRIG
  • Maximum dose: 20 IU (hRIG) and 40 IU (eRIG) per kg body weight
  • Given only once, as soon as possible and not beyond Day 7 after the first dose of vaccine.
  • Infiltrate as much as possible into the wound; the remainder of the calculated dose of RIG does not need to be injected IM at a distance from the wound but can be fractionated in smaller, individual syringes to be used for other patients, aseptic retention given.
  • If RIG is not available, thorough, prompt wound washing, together with immediate administration of the first vaccine dose, followed by a complete course of rabies vaccine.
  • Vaccines should never be withheld, regardless of the availability of RIG
  • If a limited amount of RIG is available, RIG allocation should be prioritized for exposed patients based on the following criteria: 
    • Multiple bites 
    • Deep wounds
    • Bites to highly innervated parts of the body (such as head, neck and hands)
    • Severe immunodeficiency
    • Biting animal is a confirmed or probable rabies case. 
    • Bites, scratches or exposures of mucous membranes caused by a bat.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For individuals with a recent history of rabies vaccination (within the past three months), re-exposure prophylaxis includes wound care and two doses of the rabies vaccine on days 0 and 3.

questions.text: Given the image showing significant limb swelling, which body system is likely affected?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Lymphatics

 

The image shows significant swelling of the limb, particularly in the calf region, with a characteristic "tree trunk" appearance. This presentation is indicative of lymphedema, which is a condition resulting from impairment of the lymphatic system. The swelling, shape, and involvement of the foot and toes (squaring of toes) are classic features of lymphedema.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Artery: Arterial involvement would typically cause limb wasting rather than swelling, making this option incorrect.

 

Option B. Vein: Venous involvement would present as varicose veins, which are not seen in the image, ruling out this option.

 

Option D. Muscle: Muscular involvement does not present in the characteristic way shown in the image.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Significant limb swelling with a characteristic "tree trunk" appearance in the calf region, along with swelling of the foot and squaring of the toes, is a classic presentation of lymphedema, suggesting involvement of the lymphatic system.

questions.text: Enzyme deficient in homocystinuria is: (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Cystathionine beta synthase


Homocystinuria is a genetic disorder characterized by a deficiency in the enzyme cystathionine beta synthase. This enzyme plays a crucial role in the metabolism of the amino acid methionine. When cystathionine beta synthase is deficient, it leads to the accumulation of homocysteine and methionine in the body, which can cause a range of symptoms including cardiovascular problems, skeletal abnormalities, and neurological issues.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Homocysteine: Homocysteine is an amino acid that accumulates in homocystinuria due to the deficiency of cystathionine beta synthase. It is not the enzyme that is deficient, but rather a substance that builds up as a result of the enzyme deficiency.

 

Option C. Methionine: Methionine is an essential amino acid that is part of the metabolic pathway affected in homocystinuria. The enzyme cystathionine beta synthase is involved in converting homocysteine to cystathionine, so its deficiency leads to elevated methionine levels. However, methionine is not the deficient enzyme.

 

Option D. None of the above: This option is incorrect because the enzyme deficient in homocystinuria is indeed cystathionine beta synthase.

 

Educational Objective:


Understand the enzymatic basis of homocystinuria, recognizing that the deficiency of cystathionine beta synthase leads to the accumulation of homocysteine and methionine, contributing to the clinical manifestations of the disorder.
